componenttext: This concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to The Mosaic Company First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions].Your host for today's call is Laura Gagnon, Vice President, Investor Relations of The Mosaic Company. Ms. Gagnon,
componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to The Mosaic Company First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions].
Your host for today's call is Laura Gagnon, Vice President, Investor Relations of The Mosaic Company. Ms. Gagnon, you may begin.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. Presenting today will be Ms. James O'Rourke, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rich Mack, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. We also have other members of the seni
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. Presenting today will be Ms. James O'Rourke, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Rich Mack, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. We also have other members of the senior leadership team available to answer your questions after our prepared remarks. The presentation slides we're using during the call are available on our website at mosaicco.com.
We will be making forward-looking statements during this conference call. The statement include, but are not limited to, statements about future financial and operating results. They are based on management's beliefs and expectations as of today's date and are subject to significant risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from projected results. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are included in our press release issued this morning and in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
In addition, during this call, we will present both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of GAAP and non-GAAP measures are included in the presentations slides and in today's press release. Now I would like to turn it over to Jock.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining our call. Today we're going to focus on the actions Mosaic is taking so that we can continue to successfully navigate in this market environment.The key concepts we want you to understand are: first, Mosaic's operatio
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining our call. Today we're going to focus on the actions Mosaic is taking so that we can continue to successfully navigate in this market environment.
The key concepts we want you to understand are: first, Mosaic's operational flexibility and solid balance sheet give us significant competitive advantages in a prolonged period of softer markets; second, we expect global demand for our products to be healthy, particularly, in the second half of the year; and third, this management team has been through a number of cycles, and we have the experience and discipline to position Mosaic for success across cycle.
I know that most of you understand the headwinds that we've been facing, so I won't spend a lot of time the business environment. Suffice it say, while the market environment has been challenging for crop nutrients in recent months, we fully understand and accept the cyclicality of our business.  And know from prior history, that this cycle too will turn for the better. It's our responsibility to be well-positioned when this happens. And to take advantage of opportunities the cycles present. Grain and oilseed prices up stabilized with the upper trend in recent weeks. In fact, both corn and soybean prices are higher today then they were 12 months ago. related weather conditions around the world are creating concern for the current crop, which is driving a rally in prices corn prices.
These improvements, along with expectations that U.S. farmers will plant a big crop, underpin our strong fertilizer demand outlook for the remainder of the year. Yet, fertilizer prices remain low, with our average realized prices for potash and phosphates coming in at $207 and $351 per tonne, respectively, in the first quarter. Our realized potash prices have fallen by over $80 per tonne compared with a year ago. Several factors continue to impact fertilizer prices, including the strong U.S. dollar especially against key currencies in potash-producing countries. Ample channel inventories, declining farm incomes, lower material cost, perceptional oversupply in potash, and the purchasing behavior, while the market awaits the bellwether potash contract with China.
Demand has been slower to materialize than we anticipated. A short period of warm dry weather in the corn belt in March created an expectation for an early spring, which just did not materialize as we progressed through the quarter. These conditions, taken together, led to a challenging start to the year as we expected. Mosaic earned $257 million or $0.73 per share on revenue of $1.7 billion in our first quarter. Adjusted earnings per share totaled $0.14. In the potash business, we generated $86 million in operating earnings and reported a gross margin rate of 30%, excluding resource taxes. Our phosphate operating earnings were $18 million with a gross margin rate of 7%. Phosphate margins were impacted by a smaller in-season rebound in prices than we and the timing of material costs, which Rich will address in more detail shortly.
We continue to expect a strong second half with improving global demand for the remainder of 2016. North American spring application is in full swing and we're good indications from other key regions. Demand is high in Brazil despite the political and economic turmoil. Similarly in India, a good monsoon season and a constructive nutrient resolution, including unchanged potash subsidies despite lower market prices, are driving strong application.
Our outlook for the remainder of the year includes rising demand and respectable shipment volumes, as well as traditional seasonal pricing behavior.
The recent run-up in agricultural commodity prices, combined with current due to prices, make our products very affordable. In fact, crop nutrients are more affordable today then they have been during the last 5 years. This gives us confidence in the second half outlook.
Now, let's discuss the affirmative steps we're taking to effectively manage our business and the levers that remain available. First, we are benefiting from our work to reduce expenses. Mosaic today is a low-cost producer. And we are building on this competitive advantage. Two years ago, when I was the plan to obtain $500 million in cost-savings. We are on track to achieve that goal. And we're working now to cut costs further. With the current softness in the industry, we plan to reduce support function expenses by an additional $75 million per year, and expect most of the benefit to be realized in 2017.
We're actively working on our plans in this area and intent to provide additional information and insights during our next earnings call. We also plan to reduce our capital expenditures for 2016. During our last call, we provided capital guidance of $900 million to $1.1 billion. We are reducing our 2016 guidance to $800 million to $900 million. This reduction will not compromise employee safety, or a critical sustaining capital needs. But we are deferring or elevating capital spending where we can.
In addition, we plan to continue our work to optimize our asset portfolio. We've made important progress over the last few years of my including a sale of and shutdown of MOP production at Carlsbad. We have exited underperforming businesses, regions, and assets. And we have curtailed production when the market softened. We will continue to manage our asset base to match supply with global demand environment. This is an area where we will provide more detail along with cost-saving and medium-term capital spending later this year.
At the same time, we are not just down the hatches. We're also looking for opportunities to invest and we will continue to drive a culture of innovation so that Mosaic will continue to lead the industry across all cycles.
With that, I will ask Rich Mack to provide insight as well as our guidance for the second quarter. Rich?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jock. I would like to reiterate Joc's key points. Mosaic is committed to maintaining a solid balance sheet because we understand the cyclicality of this business.We do have the ability to withstand difficult market conditions, seek opportunities
componenttext:
Thanks, Jock. I would like to reiterate Joc's key points. Mosaic is committed to maintaining a solid balance sheet because we understand the cyclicality of this business.
We do have the ability to withstand difficult market conditions, seek opportunities and emerge strong and ready to outperform in better markets.
And make no mistake, that our markets will materialize at some point. So today, I'd like to begin by providing an overview of our results in each segment.
In potash, our shipments volumes came in at the low end of our expectations. We shipped just over 1.5 million tonnes of potash, with demand in North America by weather and purchasing behavior by our customers. Potash prices drifted lower during the quarter, pressured by the seasonally slow demand, the lack of a China contract and additional product available in North America.
In light of the market dynamics, the potash gross margin rate of 30%, excluding resource taxes, was respectable. And it demonstrated our significant progress on cost control. We have made the difficult, but necessary decisions to stop higher cost production and curtail production elsewhere, and we have reduced spending across the business unit.
Our operating rate in potash was 77%, which was within our guidance range. We are continuing to manage our production to meet customer needs and global demand.
With the spring season finally in full swing in North America, demand is emerging. We expect global demand to surge that produces reach contracts with Chinese customers, which we expect to occur in the second quarter. Once that contract price has been set, we should see pent-up demand from other regions around the world, most notably, India. As a result, we now expect our global shipments for the year to be the range up 7.5 million to 8.0 million tonnes, which more than of their sales occurring in the second half of the year.
In fact, our Q2 volume guidance assumes minimal shipments to China and India. We expect prices to remain range bound, primarily due to the effects of the strong dollar and available global supply.
We anticipate average realized prices in the second quarter will be the range of $180 to $200 per tonne. Prices will continue to put pressure on margins, and our expectation for the second quarter is for the potash gross margin rate to be in the mid- to high-teens, excluding resource taxes.
The sequential decline in realized prices, the negative impact of reduced operating rates and a $50 dollar reduction in average realized prices are the main drivers of reduced segment profitability. In the Phosphate segment, shipment volumes came in at the high end of our guidance at 2.2 million tonnes.
Demand was good in Brazil and North America, while demand began to develop in India toward the end of the quarter. Market prices increased $40 per tonne in the first quarter, but we did not see quite the da magnitude of improvement we expected, mostly due to the timing of North America planting and an increase in competition from imported product.
Lower finished phosphate prices as well as the timing of raw material pricing caused our phosphate gross margin rate to fall below our expectations. We regularly discuss the impact of raw materials on our margin in phosphates. So I'd like to explain that in a bit more detail now.
There is a time lag between purchasing raw materials and selling finished phosphates. It generally takes 3 to 4 months toi raw materials to move through the finished goods inventory and cost of goods sold and to be recognized in our financials. Recently, finished phosphate prices declined faster than raw materials leading us to sell higher cost inventory at lower prices, which put pressure on margins. While raw material prices are more stable today and sales volume are picking up, phosphate prices are under pressure as Brazilians wait out the impact of the recently stranded real. While Indian importers are slow to purchase as they draw down inventories.
As a result, margins in the second quarter will remain at around 10%. We do expect both Brazil and India to import a sizable volumes later in the year, and also anticipate phosphate gross margins to return to the high-teens in the second half of 2016, where we will see the full benefits of the lower ammonia and sulfur surprises.
For the second quarter, we expect phosphate volumes to be in the range of 2.3 million to 2.6 million tonnes, with the sequential increase driven by rising seasonal demand. The year-over-year decline reflects our decision not to participate in certain geographies, most recently, for example, India, and to some extent Brazil, where current offers, in our view, do not reflect the favorable economics and ignore current global supply and demand dynamics.
Our full year volume expectations are now in the range of 9.0 million to 9.75 million tonnes with a decline driven by a slower start to 2016.
In the international distribution segment, volumes were slightly higher-than-expected. We experienced good demand in India and improving demand in Brazil, where access to farm credit began to improve last quarter. The economic and political situation in Brazil remains volatile, to say the least, and it is challenging to precisely forecast how it will affect farmers and farm credit in the months ahead. We are seeing evidence that farmers in Brazil aer continuing to plan for big crops, which bodes well for fertilizer demand.
We do not expect a meaningful improvement in international distribution profitability in the second quarter. In fact, our volume guidance reflects our decision not to pursue market share at these lower margins. The recent run-up in soybean prices, however, should help improve the profitability of our dissolution business later in the year.
Overall, we expect business conditions to improve in the second half of 2016. The three main drivers for this uptick include: one, as we said, we expect global demand for potash and phosphate to accelerate in the second half, in fact, we continue to expect a global shipments to be near all-time records; two, as a result of these saw volumes we're excited to see a higher operating rates driving lower costs in  both our potash and phosphate businesses; and three, we expect the competitive environment to level out as the robust U.S. dollar tapes in value compared to other currencies.  For example, we've already seeing the Brazilian real and the Russian ruble correct to a certain degree, and macroeconomic indicators such as that further strengthening of those the currencies is not out of the question.
Of course, that also means our higher dollar denominated operating cost for us and Canada. But we believe, we're well hedged against short-term Canadian dollar fluctuations. So, as Joc noted, in the current environment Mosaic is focused on optimizing cash flow by influencing key levers, which we have a degree of control over. This includes, producing or altogether eliminating capital spending, finding ways to further materially reduce operating and support function costs, optimizing Mosaic's portfolio of assets, driving working capital efficiency, and lastly, managing balance sheet targets relative to current liquidity requirements such as investments and/or limited.
So let's start with capital. As Joc noted, we intend to reduce capital expenditures further this year by differing, eliminating and reprioritizing investments. We expect CapEx to range from $800 million to $900 million, plus approximately $220 million for the modern project, which is down significantly from where we were projecting 3 months ago.
On a normalized basis, Mosaic will spend roughly $500 million to $550 million in sustaining capital projects. In some years this number may be higher, while in more challenging years, we will spend less. In addition to typical sustaining capital, today we have 3 distinct projects that increase our CapEx requirements to the revised range that I highlighted above.
These projects include as the K3, the joint venture and Mosaic's next-generation phosphate mine in Florida. Our modern spending will be concluded in 2017, and we will be allocating some capital for both K3 and the new phosphate mine for the next several years until completed.
Having said that, however, you should know that we are also evaluating further opportunities to reduce capital spending on the last 2 projects, as well as additional asset optimization scenarios across our entire organization. To Joc's points regarding expenses, we're moving quickly and aggressively to reduce support function cost.
We're targeting an annual run rate savings of $75 million, the majority of which should be captured in calendar year 2017. A portion will also be realized in 2016, which is in part driving a reduction in full year SG&A expenses, now expected to be the range up $340 million to $360 million, down from $350 million to $370 million provided earlier in the year.
We expect to have more detail on these initiatives on our second quarter earnings call.
Our balance sheet remains a source of strength and resilience. Our strong liquidity buffer of $2.5 billion exist for us to use when necessary, for protection in difficult parts of the cycle. Our balance sheet strength also allows us to remain committed to our dividend in today's market environment. 
So to summarize, we have a build Mosaic, it's operations, it's operations, it's talent base, and its financial foundation to succeed across cycles in a business that we know to be cyclical. We are taking the actions necessary to adapt to this environment and to ensure Mosaic remains in a strong position regardless of the market environment.
We will continue to actively assess and manage our balance sheet and we will adapt as necessary should the down part of the cycle be longer or more pronounced than expected. Now, I will turn the call back over to Joc for concluding remarks.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rich. At Mosaic, we're focused on what we can control. And we're executing, doing what we view to be the bottom of the cycle. We are reducing operating capital spending, optimizing our portfolio and using our balance sheet strength to ensure ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Rich. At Mosaic, we're focused on what we can control. And we're executing, doing what we view to be the bottom of the cycle. We are reducing operating capital spending, optimizing our portfolio and using our balance sheet strength to ensure our resilience now, and it to the better price environment that we are sure will come. We're not losing sight of long-term. We're executing all the good strategic moves we've made since 2013. Driving innovation across the company and looking for opportunities to take advantage of our relative strength. The long-term remains compelling for agriculture, crop nutrients and for Mosaic. Demand for our products continues to rise with the population, and it's never-ending demand for food.
We intend to meet the demand by managing this company prudently regardless of the market environment. Many of Mosaic's leadership team have lived through four or more agricultural commodity cycles, spending back to the mid-80s. We have the experience to manage through this cyclicality and to recognize the opportunities that it presents. Now will take your questions.

I guess, that some of the input cost-savings, but I think it phase to say that remains quite weak. So on the presentation and your prepared comments, you mentioned the phosphate gross margin will go up to 15% to 20% in the second half of this year. Can you just talk about how much of that driven by price versus benefit from loewr input costs?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Yes, let me start, Joc O'Rourke. Let me start by saying, certainly, we do expect increases in the second half as demand really takes off around the globe. And I think to really put the phosphate market into its best perspective, I'm goi
componenttext: Thank you, Andrew. Yes, let me start, Joc O'Rourke. Let me start by saying, certainly, we do expect increases in the second half as demand really takes off around the globe. And I think to really put the phosphate market into its best perspective, I'm going to allow Mike talked about what you expect from global demand towards the second half, which is really what's going to drive our second half results in phosphate.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, we have not changed our view on phosphate demand. We actually nudged up our point estimate for global shipments to about 65.6 million tonnes. And we narrowed our range from 65 to 67, to 65 to 66. If you look around the globe, at some of the key ma
componenttext: Andrew, we have not changed our view on phosphate demand. We actually nudged up our point estimate for global shipments to about 65.6 million tonnes. And we narrowed our range from 65 to 67, to 65 to 66. If you look around the globe, at some of the key markets, several positive developments there. In the case of India, I think there's a growing optimism as far as the demand prospects due to a forecast for an d above-normal monsoon event. We had some strengthening of the rupee, and we have a very workable subsidy scheme that was introduced at the end or the beginning of their fiscal year. When you look at country like Brazil, local currency prices of key commodities like soybeans, sugar, coffee are at all-time highs. We think that underpins very good demand. You look at, the fact that has been an early release of more credit. So farmers have greater flexibility, the product is moving to the farm. So lot of positive development that make us optimistic for second half demand. So what that means, Andrew, in terms of margin. Is yes, we expect some price improvement. We certainly, expect the raw material imports will benefit from that as they flow through our products. And just as importantly, you've seen our operating cost that we've really worked hard to reduce. And as operating go rates go back to more normal rates as demand picks up, our cost will further decline. So we expect to see as we said earlier, pretty normal margin rates in the second half.

componenttext: So I think your talking urinating a bit about rationalization in the potash division. Just wanted to get your thoughts on how you're thinking about K3? Is there a possibility that you ramp up the CapEx spend there and how the ability to shut down K1, K2 your operating costs as well?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for the question. Certainly, when we talk about asset rationalization, we're talking about across our global footprint. We have proven before that we can optimize our costs in some time. In terms of K3, we continue to drive K3 at an accelerated
componenttext: Thank you for the question. Certainly, when we talk about asset rationalization, we're talking about across our global footprint. We have proven before that we can optimize our costs in some time. In terms of K3, we continue to drive K3 at an accelerated rate, although, we've reduced capital this year. We've done nothing to impact of the critical path of K3. And certainly, in early next decade, we will fully understand where the market is for that and we'll be making decisions on the K3 based on those market conditions at that time. So we continue to match our production and sales with global demand and we'll rationalize our assets to satisfy that demand.

componenttext: Yes, Don. In Asia, the 2 big markets their, India, and China have been contract markets. And I think Joc did a good job of portraying it. There probably need to be some changes, but right now, when we're in the in a discussion about contractor for the remainder of the year, it doesn't do any of us any good to speculate on whether we go contract or spot. Your second question on industrial and feed accounts, there is  those contracts have a lagging  a lagging pricing formula. And that will -- those differences will become less as we get through into the second half of the year.

componenttext: Can you just comment on your executions for international phosphate prices, specifically in India and Southeast Asia? As recent times there is kind of 350-ish or even slightly lower range. You alluded this in this prepared remarks, that in general, how should we think about your intentions to participate at this levels or lack their off, particularly -- activities already oversubscribed, and just any color on your for netbacks would be greatly appreciated?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Chris, in terms of -- generally, I'm just going first just highlight that where the market pricing and over-participation, as you say, has been a high, mosaic has taken the position of actually walking away from those markets where we're not getting
componenttext: Okay. Chris, in terms of -- generally, I'm just going first just highlight that where the market pricing and over-participation, as you say, has been a high, mosaic has taken the position of actually walking away from those markets where we're not getting what we consider to be acceptable returns. Now having said that, we are price takers in the end and we have to meet market. So on the terms -- in terms of our expectation for phosphate pricing in India, I think the issue there is really about the subsidies and what the retail prices are in India and how that fits in. And for that, I'm going to ask Rick and Mike to just touch on that.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of things in terms of possible second half pricing. One, I think we mentioned before that we think we mentioned before that we think there could be a pretty strong of demand. we think Brazil will be in the market, India will be in the market
componenttext: Just a couple of things in terms of possible second half pricing. One, I think we mentioned before that we think we mentioned before that we think there could be a pretty strong of demand. we think Brazil will be in the market, India will be in the market, and North America will be all active at pretty much the same time. So there is the potential for some strong seasonal pressures, we believe. I think the second point is that, raw material costs have come down a lot. And then that's been part of the reason for the drop in the phosphate prices. And those costs are beginning to stabilize. So I don't think there's going to be quite as many tailwinds from lower raw material costs. And then, a third point is, some of the currency changes that have taken place, is beginning to pinch margins for some of those producers, who greatly benefited from a depreciated currency. And then finally, as Joc mentioned, the subsidies that was announced in India, is a very workable subsidy. And I think it remains to be seen how the markets sort of sorts out the spoils of that subsidy. If there's a punching and you get some price pressure, certainly, the Indians can afford to pay more. We've done some real simple analysis that shows if retail prices drop slightly in India, certainly the Indians can afford to pay prices up into the 380s. So I think, there is the potential there for a lots of things combining to provide some uplift in price in the second half.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think Mike you nailed it on the impact of India and Southeast Asia pricing. I think the good thing to look at is in the near term, we've seen an uptick in prices in the India and in the Pakistan.  Which is a good first step at a time when Indians h
componenttext: Yes, I think Mike you nailed it on the impact of India and Southeast Asia pricing. I think the good thing to look at is in the near term, we've seen an uptick in prices in the India and in the Pakistan.  Which is a good first step at a time when Indians have deferred buying. So when they come with full force, we think that creates a different pricing environment. Than if I was in India buyer, I'd be stepping in and getting some cover at these levels. And as we look at what the impact is on netbacks, we -- Joc talked about it earlier. But we see slight improvement in prices. We see the impact of our raw materials in the second half hitting us positively. And we see the fact that, with the plants running at a more normalized operational rate, we see all those 3 things positively impacting our margins.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joc. With respect your first question, yes, it is apples-to-apples, and it really goes to, I think, it was Don's question earlier, and that is, we benefited in the first quarter from a -- some of the industrial and sales that are at higher prices
componenttext: Thanks, Joc. With respect your first question, yes, it is apples-to-apples, and it really goes to, I think, it was Don's question earlier, and that is, we benefited in the first quarter from a -- some of the industrial and sales that are at higher prices compared to where they will be in the second quarter. Recently, we've seen a decline, in example, and SOP. And that results in some recalibrating for prices, just to give 1 example. Then on Ma'aden, what you should assume there is, this is basically a timing issue with respect to capital. We would effectively guide exactly as we have in the past, and that is ammonia prices -- ammonia production will start in the fourth quarter of this year. I think we're anticipating somewhere in the vicinity of 300,000 tonnes of ammonia that would be produced Ma'aden joint venture in 2016. Phosphate production will start sometime in the middle part of 2017. Both of those points in time are generally consistent with what we talked about previously. So think of the deferral in capital in 2016 related to Ma'aden to be something that will be picked up in 2017.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Next question comes from Joel Jackson with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: If you can talk a little bit about the strategy in Brazil on potash. I'm understanding the distribution on -- the distribution your distribution about tonnes from using your suppliers this past 2 months to try to ease some of the burden in the country. And also, I know a few months ago when prices where low as $210 a tonne, your distribution arm was going in trying to buy tonnes and couldn't. Can you talk About now if you're going and trying to buy tonnes at 215 and 220. If you're finding volume from European competitors on potash?

componenttext: I'm going to just hand this straight over to Rick. This question has come up before, and I think we need to probably nip it.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joy, thanks for your question. As far as our ids business, we did step in and tonnes outside of Canpotex is our primary supplier, in fact, our soul supplier. But we did step in during the period where they had less tonnes going into the market and bought
componenttext: Joy, thanks for your question. As far as our ids business, we did step in and tonnes outside of Canpotex is our primary supplier, in fact, our soul supplier. But we did step in during the period where they had less tonnes going into the market and bought some from third parties. That continues into the second quarter. It's not a huge amount of tonnes. And frankly, we've been able to manage through kind of a tightness in the marketplace. So that's first. There was some question of us buying up some tonnes in North America and trying to move them into this revision business taking an arbitration on the price spreads from the Senegal to move them into our Brazil business. That we could not recollect up enough to make that -- make it a vessel truly work. But that arbitration is there. And if prices remain lower in North America, that would surely be opportunity for somebody to play that game.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ben Isaacson with Scotiabank.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ben Isaacson with Scotiabank.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at slide 23 on P&K shipments to China. And I just wanted -- I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about how influential China is on your phosphate business, particularly, with respect to -- do you see that capacity growing or shrinki
componenttext: Just looking at slide 23 on P&K shipments to China. And I just wanted -- I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about how influential China is on your phosphate business, particularly, with respect to -- do you see that capacity growing or shrinking, over the next couple of years? Are the Chinese price setters either all year ro perhaps seasonal basis, and are the Chinese disciplined when it comes to phosphate production?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, most of this I'm going to hand over to Mike, who really takes -- spends a lot of time analyzing this market very carefully. And I think, though I will say in general, our expectations -- and I think if you read the major analysts companies, their exp
componenttext: Ben, most of this I'm going to hand over to Mike, who really takes -- spends a lot of time analyzing this market very carefully. And I think, though I will say in general, our expectations -- and I think if you read the major analysts companies, their expectation is Chinese capacity over time, will remain flat or possibly shrink. So that's basically what's in our plan. But I think to give better detail, I'm going to hand it straight to Mike.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess several components to that question. Let's talk about the export numbers first. According to Chinese customs statistics, first quarter exports were down about 560,000 tonnes from a year ago. We think that that will continue in the last three
componenttext: Sure. I guess several components to that question. Let's talk about the export numbers first. According to Chinese customs statistics, first quarter exports were down about 560,000 tonnes from a year ago. We think that that will continue in the last three quarters of the year. And our last estimate from our Chinese team indicates that, we believe, that Chinese exports will be down about 2 million tonnes for the year from a record 11.7 million last year to about 9.6 million tonnes this year. As you know, the Chinese have stopped building phosphate plants after this dramatic expansion over the past 10 years. And as Joc mentioned, we think that there will be some restructuring that takes place in what's a very heterogeneous industry there. And that over time, exports probably will stabilize somewhere in that 7 million to 8 million tonne range. There is an analog, if you look that what happened on the nitrogen side of the business, I think, 2015 was the first year were closures of ammonia capacity exceeded increases in capacity. And so, capacity in China can decline, and we think, that over the next 5 years, you'll see a significant restructuring, and China, becomes of certainly a large, but a more stable player in our market.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about the cycle being cyclically weak at this juncture. Notwithstanding that, is that the case that you contemplate any meaningful acquisitions? And should you make some -- how much are you willing to leverage your balance Sheet?
componenttext: You talked about the cycle being cyclically weak at this juncture. Notwithstanding that, is that the case that you contemplate any meaningful acquisitions? And should you make some -- how much are you willing to leverage your balance Sheet?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Jeff, so if I understand are we contemplating acquisitions and what would be willing to lever? let me start this off, and I'm going to hand it to Rich. Yes, we look at this part of the cycle And we're actively looking for opportunities to grow our c
componenttext: Okay. Jeff, so if I understand are we contemplating acquisitions and what would be willing to lever? let me start this off, and I'm going to hand it to Rich. Yes, we look at this part of the cycle And we're actively looking for opportunities to grow our company over the long-term. And we believe this part of the cycle, maybe opening up opportunities for value that might not exist in other parts of the cycle. That being said, our basic philosophy is any acquisition we make, has to meet a return on capital requirement that meets cost to capital, plus a risk premium, plus a return to shareholders. And then, with the share price where it is today, we have the added need of it having to compete with the potential to just buyback our own chairs. In terms of leveraging up, yes, we would be able to lever up. And we have said before, we would go beyond our normal 2:1 debt-to-EBITDA ratio for the right investment. But realize that we are very conscious of our credit rating. And we're committed to maintaining that. Now having said that, we expect any acquisition would come with its own earnings, which would offset some of that.  Rich, do you want to add some color to that?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you covered it, Joc. I would just say, Jeff, Mosaic would be disciplined through any process that we undertake. And, I think we noted this before, Mosaic was essentially evolved through acquisitions during the down part of the cycle. And so there
componenttext: I think you covered it, Joc. I would just say, Jeff, Mosaic would be disciplined through any process that we undertake. And, I think we noted this before, Mosaic was essentially evolved through acquisitions during the down part of the cycle. And so there certainly are opportunities that come in front of us. I've mentioned before, almost any phosphate or potash opportunity will come across our desk. And if the circumstances are right we have the balance sheet capability to do it, and we definitely will stay disciplined and we are committed to maintaining of investment-grade credit rating.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one other point, Jeff, I just want to make -- this discipline means, we're going to be just as happy to walk away from things if we can't get them at the price that we believe as value to our shareholders.
componenttext: And one other point, Jeff, I just want to make -- this discipline means, we're going to be just as happy to walk away from things if we can't get them at the price that we believe as value to our shareholders.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Your next question is from Mark with CLSA.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joc, you mentioned declining farm income in your opening comments. But how significant role that has actually played with prices going down? And I measured, nutrients got cheaper and farm income didn't really go down that much in North America this year.
componenttext: Joc, you mentioned declining farm income in your opening comments. But how significant role that has actually played with prices going down? And I measured, nutrients got cheaper and farm income didn't really go down that much in North America this year. So I'm just curious, you listed it as one of several issues, but how big is it really?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, actually its a great point. Rick, and I were with one of our major customers just last week. And they have a relatively detailed analysis of the different costs. And of all the cost, I think, potash and potash amounted to $61 per acre on a farm in y
componenttext: Mark, actually its a great point. Rick, and I were with one of our major customers just last week. And they have a relatively detailed analysis of the different costs. And of all the cost, I think, potash and potash amounted to $61 per acre on a farm in your Indiana, Illinois-type area. Interestingly enough, your life to some chemicals came to a higher number than that. Nitrogen came to over a $100, and over $100. So if you look at a farmer and affordability from just that analysis, it really say's that if a farmer wants to maximize his revenue from every acre, the last thing you should be doing today is compromising the amount of fertilizer he puts down. Rick, did you want to add anything to that?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. And I think that changes in commodity prices have truly been positive given where nutrient prices are at. I think the issue is that, in a period with everyone, where farmers have lived with prices that are much higher than they are today, there is a p
componenttext: No. And I think that changes in commodity prices have truly been positive given where nutrient prices are at. I think the issue is that, in a period with everyone, where farmers have lived with prices that are much higher than they are today, there is a percentage of farmers that at today's prices and nutrient cost and all the inputs, aren't going to make money. And I think, that's one thing -- that's why we mentioned it is that, we're going to go through a period where we just have to understand what real farm income is. And whether it's in Brazil or in North America, we see those things happening. Mike?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing, if you look at North American shipments of potash and phosphate. I mean they have done remarkably for the last 5 years or since the financial crisis. And both on them right in that 9 million metric tonnes. Well, there might be front page
componenttext: The other thing, if you look at North American shipments of potash and phosphate. I mean they have done remarkably for the last 5 years or since the financial crisis. And both on them right in that 9 million metric tonnes. Well, there might be front page stories in the Wall Street Journal, but the difficulty of farmer indicator Illinois. That the proof is in the pudding as well as the actual shipments have been very, very constant.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from P.J. Juvekar with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from P.J. Juvekar with Citigroup.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dan on for PJ. Just wanted to clarify one thing, that $500 million cost-savings program you a few years back, is that complete? And if not, how much you have left to get on that? And secondly, if I recall correctly, you are start a this past quart
componenttext: This is Dan on for PJ. Just wanted to clarify one thing, that $500 million cost-savings program you a few years back, is that complete? And if not, how much you have left to get on that? And secondly, if I recall correctly, you are start a this past quarter. Did that start off? And maybe talk about the impacts on your could be?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The let me start with the $500 million. The $500 million program was 5-year program to take out reoccurring costs over that time frame. We announced that 3 years ago. And I would say, we're probably -- certainly on track for it and probably a little bit a
componenttext: The let me start with the $500 million. The $500 million program was 5-year program to take out reoccurring costs over that time frame. We announced that 3 years ago. And I would say, we're probably -- certainly on track for it and probably a little bit ahead of track. We still have some areas where we think we can get some further reductions in both G&A and operating costs. But you can see in our results that, a good chunk of that is flowing through our results today as you well aware. I mean our potash costs are flat despite a 16% reduction in our operating rates. Our phosphate conversion costs are lower despite a significantly lower operating rate. And we held on phosphate rate flat for several years. And all this is part of the program. We've also -- you can see our SG&A cost this year down 10%. So overall, you can see the results as they flow through, but we still have some cost left to come. going very well. In terms of the sulfur That sulfur is now running. We're about probably have the biggest impact and you've seen the sulfur prices in the Gulf come down recently. I think what it's done, is it forced the trade flow to go to what makes the best sense. And so what we'll see in terms of costs, is probably not a significant decrease, but what we will see is the liquid sulfur market going down to trading at a discount to solid market -- sulfur again as it has 5, 10 years ago.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Steve Byrne with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from Steve Byrne with Bank of America.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I had a few remarks earlier about the outlook for Indian and Brazil. I wanted to just drill into U.S. and China a bit here. And with respect to the U.S., given your view of applications of P&K and where the spring looks like it's trailing out here.
componenttext: Mike, I had a few remarks earlier about the outlook for Indian and Brazil. I wanted to just drill into U.S. and China a bit here. And with respect to the U.S., given your view of applications of P&K and where the spring looks like it's trailing out here. Would you say that P&K applications in this fertilizer year we're in right now will fall short of historical levels, or compared to say, what was removed with last year's harvest? So that's a U.S. question. One over on China. It appears to us that yield -- crop yields in that country, could be constrained by underapplication of potash, in spite of overapplication of nitrogen with -- would be interested in your view on that? And what do you think is a mechanism for that -- those to change over time?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All the questions, I'm going to hand it straight to Mike to go through this. We want to get throughout these questions.
componenttext: All the questions, I'm going to hand it straight to Mike to go through this. We want to get throughout these questions.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks Steve. I will make some comments, and I think probably have some comments as well. In the U.S. as far as the spring application season goes, I guess, we would characterize it as a strong season. We're seeing good shipments, no indication of c
componenttext: Okay, thanks Steve. I will make some comments, and I think probably have some comments as well. In the U.S. as far as the spring application season goes, I guess, we would characterize it as a strong season. We're seeing good shipments, no indication of changes in application rates. And as you mentioned before, we believe that P&K shipments will continue to be in that 9 million metric tonne rage. So that's a situation in the U.S. And obviously, the spring season is pretty much complete and history, and now we're begin to look ahead to fall season. And certainly, when you look at future prices, you have corn and soybeans still at relatively high levels. Assuming there is a decent crop and a good pool of nutrients, we have no reason to think that the fall application season is going to let up at all. And I guess a positive in North America, we think, the pipeline has been pulled down to a much more normal levels or even lower levels after having seen some elevated stocks. In China, yes, I think your point is spot on. We expect that, as you know, China has announced 0 growth policy after 2020. And they've also announced some changes in their crop support prices. I think all of that, and in terms of no growth, I think you'll see may be a reallocation of nutrients between from nitrogen into phosphate and especially potash. And I think there's some evidence of that taking place already, because last year, China has record potash imports of 9 million tonnes, domestic production is up. And their potash shipments are on the rise. And I think clearly, there is evidence of acknowledging the problem you bring up. Rick, do you have any?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you have done it
componenttext: No, I think you have done it

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from John Roberts with UBS.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you don't get a Chinese potash agreement this quarter, I assume your fully outlook will be worse, because pent-up demand would continue to be a deferred. But do you think that price would still be stable in that scenario? That is the thing that price m
componenttext: If you don't get a Chinese potash agreement this quarter, I assume your fully outlook will be worse, because pent-up demand would continue to be a deferred. But do you think that price would still be stable in that scenario? That is the thing that price may have stabilized in part here because of expectations of a near-term agreement, and things could get sloppy if you don't get that?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to hand that straight to Rick just to answer that.
componenttext: I'm going to hand that straight to Rick just to answer that.

componenttext: I guess, John, our expectation is for the contract to get completed with the Chinese during the second quarter. So if it didn't happen, I think that how we operate would be to matchup our production to what we believe the market is going to be. And we'll continue to operate that way.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Michael begin Michael Piken with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from Michael begin Michael Piken with Cleveland Research.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. The first one, it sounds like you are longer-term strategy, I mean, if the market on potash in particular, at least be oversupplied. What is the potential for Canpotex to continue to -- Canpotex Solutions to continue to p
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. The first one, it sounds like you are longer-term strategy, I mean, if the market on potash in particular, at least be oversupplied. What is the potential for Canpotex to continue to -- Canpotex Solutions to continue to production, other producers are running high operating rates, typically high on the cost rate than you guys?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Look, let me start by saying -- and we've reiterating a point I think we've made a number of times, which is, we don't see the market as really being all that out of balance. You have a weak market today, because of cyclicality. You also have the im
componenttext: Okay. Look, let me start by saying -- and we've reiterating a point I think we've made a number of times, which is, we don't see the market as really being all that out of balance. You have a weak market today, because of cyclicality. You also have the impact of seasonality. And then the 2 have combined to create a situation that's pretty difficult for that market. That being said, we believe once the normal flow stats, i.e. once the Chinese contract is in place, once India starts buying and they get a contract in place, the demand gets up pretty darn quickly, and that everybody goes back to more normal operating rates. So when you ask the long-term, Canpotex will continue to match our expectations or Canpotex and Mosaic will match global demand with our available production as we have in the first quarter. And we don't see any reason for that to change at this point.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Sandy Klugman with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Sandy Klugman with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, how the challenging backdrop for growers impact the demand for higher margin products such as MicroEssentials. Second question is, any thoughts on how India is phosphate gas settlement will impact the region's desire to import
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, how the challenging backdrop for growers impact the demand for higher margin products such as MicroEssentials. Second question is, any thoughts on how India is phosphate gas settlement will impact the region's desire to import that versus producing of product locally? And finally, on the longer-term supply demand balance for the phosphate industry, what are your thoughts on how quickly the OCP will bring new granulation capacity?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank's, Sandy. There are 3 there I'm going to try and get all 3. First of all, MicroEssentials, are limited to selling MicroEssentials. So far has been production capacity. We've just completed a $225 million increase in capacity. Our New Wales pla
componenttext: Okay. Thank's, Sandy. There are 3 there I'm going to try and get all 3. First of all, MicroEssentials, are limited to selling MicroEssentials. So far has been production capacity. We've just completed a $225 million increase in capacity. Our New Wales plant, which will give us the capacity to produce 3.5 million tonnes. As per the earlier question about the economics of buying fertilizer, we believe the economics of using MicroEssentials is better than it's ever been because of the challenging market, not despite the challenging market. So I would say, first of all, we expect the careful producer will be doing everything they can to increase the per accre, which include using the best quality premium products, which would be like our MicroEssentials product or K-Mag or any of those products that tend to bring on better yield. In terms of to India, I'm going to throw that straight over to Rick.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, with the asset contract into India, I think there's already been contracts closed in the Europe that are at higher levels. I think how the Indian producers think about their contract is, they are producing more NPK's, because that allows them to up m
componenttext: Yes, with the asset contract into India, I think there's already been contracts closed in the Europe that are at higher levels. I think how the Indian producers think about their contract is, they are producing more NPK's, because that allows them to up maximize their return from the subsidy. And if you look, in our forecast, we show less DAP being produced in India, which in turn leads to more imports.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I will just quickly touch on the OCP. Obviously, we don't have any information that you don't have that's been publicly stated. But OCP has publicly stated that they will contribute, I believe, half the world's growth by their granulation growth. So a
componenttext: And I will just quickly touch on the OCP. Obviously, we don't have any information that you don't have that's been publicly stated. But OCP has publicly stated that they will contribute, I believe, half the world's growth by their granulation growth. So assuming that is exactly what they will do. We have time for one last question on the fingers, so let's keep moving.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from HSBC Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from HSBC Bank.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The question actually is on your balance sheet, and on some idea of capital allocation. In the past, you've talked about keeping of $1 billion cash buffer on balance sheet. There's a chance, I guess, with lower profits and good amount of capital spending,
componenttext: The question actually is on your balance sheet, and on some idea of capital allocation. In the past, you've talked about keeping of $1 billion cash buffer on balance sheet. There's a chance, I guess, with lower profits and good amount of capital spending, that you may eat into that buffer and go lower than the $1 billion of cash in the balance sheet. So I'm curious to know, how much or how low can you go or do you want to go below that $1 billion mark for cash on balance sheet before something critical happen like you have to dividend or take some serious cuts into your capital spending?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jonah, let me quickly touch on this and then I'll hand it to Rich for a second. The liquidity buffer we carry is $2.5 billion. And exactly, what the name implies, it is buffer for short-term liquidity. Today, we have announced significant cost reductions,
componenttext: Jonah, let me quickly touch on this and then I'll hand it to Rich for a second. The liquidity buffer we carry is $2.5 billion. And exactly, what the name implies, it is buffer for short-term liquidity. Today, we have announced significant cost reductions, further capital reductions, to minimize the impact on that liquidity buffer. But if our cash needs exceed our short-term generation, we will dip into that buffer. Rich, do you want to say anything on that?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that you should just think of what end goal here is, to have about $2.5 billion of total available liquidity, and that can be comprised of either cash on balance sheet or available revolver capacity. And so, at times, that will fluctuate
componenttext: Yes, I would say that you should just think of what end goal here is, to have about $2.5 billion of total available liquidity, and that can be comprised of either cash on balance sheet or available revolver capacity. And so, at times, that will fluctuate up and down. Today, we have a very strong balance sheet cash balance in our balance sheet. And we certainly, we believe with the conservative way in which we have managed our balance sheet in the past, we've got the opportunity to weather any market challenges that might come our way.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, with that, I would like to close off. And let me just make a couple of closing comments. I know at least one of the company reporting today. So we don't want to cut into their time. Look, we fully expect the markets to strengthen as the year progres
componenttext: Okay, with that, I would like to close off. And let me just make a couple of closing comments. I know at least one of the company reporting today. So we don't want to cut into their time. Look, we fully expect the markets to strengthen as the year progresses. With that said, year-to-date, our production rates are down, consistent with our intention to balance production with sales and global demand. I want to highlight some positive steps we've taken to reduce our spending for the Mosaic to weather this current environment, and drive across cycle. We've held our production cost flat year-over-year in potash despite a 16% reduction in our operating rate. This represents would cost management as well as some currency benefits. I want to point out our inflow focus. While somewhat depend on mother nature, these are down by $70 million to $90 million from the peak, largely due to would cost control, good technology application and some currency benefits. In phosphates, we've driven our conversion cost lower Despite a significant low operating rate. And we held the cash cost of our mining operations flat over several years. We actually both of those to good cost management. We've reduced of annual capital spending expectations this year by $200 million, plus deferred almost $100 million in spending Our SG&A costs are down 10% year-over-year as lower incentives are driven by our performance, and our performance reflect the challenging market environment. And we've lowered our full year SG&A guidance. This clearly demonstrates the benefits of our work to continue to be the low-cost producer in potash and phosphates. So with that, I want to conclude our call by reiterating our key messages. We have the operating flexibility and balance sheet, we need to weather the current market environment, we fully expect the markets to improve in the second half of this year, and we understand, and are prepared for the cyclical nature of this business. The long-term remains very promising, and we manage this company for long-term success. Thank you for joining the call. Have a great day. Thank you.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
