componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mosaic Company's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Your host for today's call is Laura Gagnon, Vice President, Investor Relations of the Mosaic company. Ms.  Gagnon, you may begin.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to our second quarter 2016 earnings call. Presenting today will be Joc O'Rourke, President and Chief Executive Officer; Rich Mack, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Dr. Mike, Vice President, Strategy and Mark
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to our second quarter 2016 earnings call. Presenting today will be Joc O'Rourke, President and Chief Executive Officer; Rich Mack, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Dr. Mike, Vice President, Strategy and Market Analysis. We also have other members of the senior leadership team available to answer your questions after our prepared remarks. 
The presentation slides we are using during the call are available on our website at mosaicco.com.
We will be making forward-looking statements during this conference call. The statements include, but are not limited to, statements about future financial and operating results. They are based management's beliefs and expectations as of today's date and are subject to significant risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from projected results. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements are included in our press release issued this morning and in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
In addition, during this call, we will present both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measure. Reconciliations of GAAP to non-GAAP measures are in today's press release. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joc.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining our second quarter earnings discussion. Today, we're going to discuss 2 primary topics: the market environment and the actions we are taking to ensure Mosaic is competitive at all points in the cycle. Let's start with
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining our second quarter earnings discussion. Today, we're going to discuss 2 primary topics: the market environment and the actions we are taking to ensure Mosaic is competitive at all points in the cycle. 
Let's start with the markets. We thought it would be useful for you to hear directly from Dr. Micron, who leads market and strategic analysis for Mosaic. Mike has been analyzing global agriculture and the fertilizer markets for decades, so it's safe to say that he understands a wide range of market conditions. Mike?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joc. Let me start by acknowledging the obvious. Industry phosphate and potash margins have declined significantly as evidenced in our earnings so far this year as well as our third quarter guidance. The drivers and the downturn range from a collap
componenttext:
Thanks, Joc. Let me start by acknowledging the obvious. Industry phosphate and potash margins have declined significantly as evidenced in our earnings so far this year as well as our third quarter guidance. The drivers and the downturn range from a collapse of key phosphate and potash currencies to the deferral of demand this year to elevate the channel inventories, to the start-up or even the expectation of the start up of new capacity. 
Buyer sentiment remains cautious for several reasons, such as volatile crop prices and exchange rate on uncertainties. But we do think the global supply and demand balance is not as far out of kilter as current prices indicate. More importantly, low prices are causing material adjustments on both the supply and demand side of the ledger. High cost production is moving off-line and demand is accelerating, especially in key growth markets.
On the demand side, prospects remain solid. In fact, we have not changed our P&K shipment guidance for 2016.  We still Project that global phosphate shipments will total 65 million to 66 million tonnes this year and global MOP shipments will total 59 million to 60 million tonnes despite the long delays in settling contracts with Chinese and Indian buyers. 
Furthermore, we see a high likelihood of seasonal bunching of demand for both P&K in the second half of the year. Our first look at 2017 indicates that phosphate shipments are forecast decline to 66 million to 68 million tonnes and global MOP shipments are projected to increase to 61 million to 63 million tonnes next year. 
Several economic and agronomic factors underpin this constructive outlook. First, plant nutrients remain affordable despite lower and volatile crop prices. In fact, our affordability metric at the end of July indicated that plant nutrients were 21% more affordable than the average since 2010. It's worth noting that our affordability metric is calculated using only corn, soybean and wheat prices and crop prices are that moving in lockstep. Corn, soybean and wheat prices have fallen, while either prices including sugar, cotton and coffee have increased significantly this year.
Second, shipment prospects are bolstered by the pull down of channel inventory so far this year, especially throughout the Americas. Our sales team tells us that channel inventories side are thin, heading into what is expected to be another very good fall application season in North America. 
In Brazil, the most recent statistics show that phosphate and potash inventories throughout the distribution channel shrunk nearly 600,000 tonnes and almost 200,000 tonnes, respectively, during the first half of this year. 
Third, Brazilian demand forecast just keep getting revised higher and higher despite the chaotic political backdrop, a volatile exchange rate and tight farm credit. That is not a surprise, given record high local currency prices for soybeans, corn, sugar, cotton and coffee. Based on record first half shipments, our team now projects that total fertilizer shipments will top 32 million tonnes this year, up 10% from forecast just 6 months ago. Shipments this year could best the previous high mark of 32.2 million in 2014.
Fourth, demand in India looks to be back on a solid growth trajectory. The monsoon is delivering above average rainfall across nearly all of the country for the first time in 3 years. In addition, the combination of lower international prices, modest cuts in subsidies and the relatively stable  rupee has resulted in declines in retail debt and MOP prices of roughly 15% and 30%, respectively, and sets the stage for strong P&K use. 
Demand prospects in other Latin American and Asian countries, such as Argentina and Pakistan, remained positive. Furthermore, significant demand is emerging from other regions, such as the former Soviet Union and Africa that are not necessarily on most radar screens. On the supply-side of the ledger, several adjustments have occurred and more are under way today. In the case of phosphate, China has shattered capacity as evidenced by the 1.5 million tonne decline in debt, MOP, and TSP exports during the first half of this year. Restructuring of China's large phosphate sector is beginning to take place, and plans outlined at the national Phosphate and Compound Fertilizer Industry Association's Annual Conference in May call for the permanent closure of outdated facilities with capacity of 3 million tonnes of P205  or the equivalent of 6.5 million  tonnes of DAP by the end of this decade.
In the case of potash, large producers continue to optimize operations by idling or shutting the higher cost facilities and maximizing operating rates at lower cost facilities in order to complete with produces who have benefited from a collapse of their currencies. For example, all of the North American facilities that were at the right end of every estimate of the industry cost curve had closed. The closure of 6 North American mines has resulted in a net loss of 2.25 million tonnes of capacity.
Finally, foreign exchange tailwinds are beginning to diminish for some producers. Currencies like the ruble are recovering along with the price of oil. Inflation, as expected, is picking up in this countries and most importantly, P&K prices have come down significantly. 
In our view, the large drop in potash prices is more the result of the collapse of key potash currencies rather than a surge of new capacity. This is an important part of our thesis that fundamentals are in better balance than current P&K prices would indicate. 
In summary, adjustments are taking place in response to low prices and margins. Demand is beginning to accelerate and high costs capacity are shutting them. As a result, we project relatively stable global phosphate and potash operating rates through the rest of this decade. While we're not widely bullish, we see some positive developments that market seem to be ignoring or discounting for now. Joc?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that insight, Mike. Clearly, the current environment is very challenging even with a strong global demand Mike describe. While this weak part of the cycle's been more pronounced than we anticipated, we do understand commodity businesses are cyc
componenttext:
Thanks for that insight, Mike. Clearly, the current environment is very challenging even with a strong global demand Mike describe. While this weak part of the cycle's been more pronounced than we anticipated, we do understand commodity businesses are cyclical and that the trough can be difficult. We also understand the imperative to navigate the trough for enhancing our ability to outperform in better times. We are taking the necessary actions to do just that. We're conserving cash and protecting our balance sheet, so that we can continue to meet our customer's needs and seek opportunities to drive future shareholder value. 
We've taken a number of steps to reduce costs. First, we're well on our way to achieving the 5-year $500 million expense reduction goal we established almost 3 years ago. The cuts have been implemented across the business. 
Second, on our last earnings call, we told you that we are targeting an additional $75 million in savings in our support functions. With the actions we took in June, we are well on our way to achieving that goal.
Third, we are continuing to optimize our assets so that we can produce enough crop nutrients to meet our customers' demand, while reducing our cost per tonne.
With the decision to idle our potash mine for the remainder of 2016, we will be able to meet market demands with our lower cost bill play in mines as well as our existing potash inventory.
And fourth, we're managing our capital carefully with without starving our operations or risking employees' safety. We are differing or permanently eliminating capital spending when and where we can. All of these decisions have reduced our cost. Our MOP cash production cost per tonne came in this quarter at $98 per tonne, which included $21 per tonne of brine management cost. For the first half of 2016, our MOP cash cost came in at $93 per tonne, which is $74 of direct production costs and $19 per tonne of brand management cost. This was comparable to last year despite a much lower operating rate. It is important to highlight that every big producer has its own cost curve mine by mine, and you can see ours on the slide.
When we run our Esterhazy and Belle Plaine mines at optimal rates as we intend to do in the second half of 2016 with down, we can achieve significantly lower cost. Esterhazy is capable of achieving direct production cash cost per tonne close to $50 when we eliminate management cost in the mid-2020s, and Belle Plaine can produce at approximately $70 per tonne.
As a reminder, we look at our cost excluding Brian expenses because Brian management is largely a fixed cost. As you know, we have a plan to eliminate Brian expenses over time. Our costs are also well controlled in phosphate even with lower operating rates. 
So we are making good progress, but we're not conserving cash just to weather the market storm. We are mindful that opportunities arise at the low points of the cycle and especially when the low point last longer than usual. Of course, we will maintain our strategic discipline as we consider potential opportunities. 
In total, yes, the business environment is challenging, but we believe in the bright future of this industry and of Mosaic. We are managing aggressively to ensure the company's competitiveness for now and for better markets. It is in times like this that management can make a real difference. 
Now before we take your questions, I'll ask Rich Mack to provide a bit more detail on the quarter as well as our guidance.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joc. I would like to reiterate the key points made by both Mike and Joc. No doubt, our markets are challenging right now with prices failing to rise even with strong global demand. That said, though, we do expect conditions to improve in the secon
componenttext:
Thanks, Joc. I would like to reiterate the key points made by both Mike and Joc. No doubt, our markets are challenging right now with prices failing to rise even with strong global demand. That said, though, we do expect conditions to improve in the second half of the year. 
Mosaic has the ability to withstand challenging conditions longer if necessary and to thrive as market prices improve. As a reminder, Mosaic has a $2.5 billion liquidity buffer, which remains untapped so we continue to have ample financial flexibility even during this down part of the  cycle. 
The notable items this quarter, which netted out to a negative $37 million or $0.09 a share, included $69 million in after-tax charges that reflect our deliberate focus on reducing spend and preserving cash. We recorded charges for severance, the write-down of the initial construction of a second ammonia barge and for our share of the decision not to pursue Encanto Canpotex port project at Prince Rupert. 
Now I'd like to provide a brief review of our results and our expectations for each segment.
In potash, our sales volumes for the second quarter were within our guidance range, which anticipated a lack of shipments to India and China. Prices fell further during the quarter with Mosaic recording an average realized price of $178 per tonne. With uncertainty in China and India now resolved, we expect that the pricing floor is now established with the third quarter potash prices to be in the range of $160 to $175 per tonne, which reflects a heavier mix of lower-priced exports sales.
As Joc noted, the shutdown will be to a lower operating of around 65%. Not withstanding , however, we're maintaining our annual sales guidance of 7.5 million to 8.0 million  tonnes of potash.
In the second quarter, our potash gross margin rate was 12% and 20% excluding Canadian resource taxes. As you know, we have been relentlessly focused on costs, which has helped us maintain reasonable margins during the downturn. 
In the third quarter, we expect gross margin rate to decline as a result of lower prices and the impact of a lower operating rate.
In phosphate, second quarter sales volumes were well within our guidance ranges as global demand remains strong. Our average realized price came in at the low end of our guidance range, while raw material costs also declined. The result was a gross margin rate of 10%, which was in line with our expectations.
We expect the gross margin rate in phosphates to stay around 10% with additional benefit from lower sulfur and ammonia costs, offsetting expected lower realized prices and higher phosphate rock costs. We plan to run our phosphate facilities at a relatively high operating rate in order to meet North American fall demand. Our guidance for third quarter phosphate sales is 2.4 million to 2.7 million tonnes. 
In the International Distribution segment, as Mike noted, demand is strong in Brazil and India, and the agricultural situation in both of these key regions remains promising. Our margins in International Distribution continue to be muted by lower fertilizer prices. For the third quarter, we expect International Distribution sales to be in a range of 2.1 million to 2.4 million tonnes and a sequential improvement in profitability, with the gross margin dollars per tonne in the $15 to $20 range, which assumes a stable real.
We have lowered again our full year SG&A guidance to be in the range of $330 million to $350 million, down from the initial guidance of $350 million to $370 million. Just as a reminder, SG&A at Mosaic was $394 million in 2013, prior to the CF and EDM acquisitions.
We have also lowered our capital expenditures by an additional $50 million this quarter to a range of $750 million to $850 million, which is in addition to our investment in the joint venture, which was $220 million in 2016.
The cost of the lower expected earnings, we are revising our effective tax rate guidance to be around 10% for 2016. We have also lowered our expected full year brine management costs from $150 million to $170 million compared to our prior estimate of $160 million to $180 million.
Finally, we expect Canadian resource taxes to range from $95 million to $110 million in 2016. 
To summarize, we continue to benefit from our strong financial foundation, and we are pulling the necessary levers to ensure that we can compete across the cycle. We now have the long desired clarity on China and India potash needs and, along with strong global demand and supply adjustments, we believe potash prices have bottomed and we see potential for modest price increases in the second half of the year. 
In what we believe will be an improving environment, we will continue to assess the market and our respective balance sheet in capital management positions, and we will adapt come as necessary as the business environment evolves. 
With that, I'm going to turn the call back over to Joc to moderate our Q&A session.

componenttext: This is stepping in for Ben.  Joc, now do you have lower CapEx guidance for the past 2 quarters. Is this largely a function of potash ramp up deferral? Or is this a cost savings taking there as well? And how should we think about the case we ramped up schedule going forward?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Carl. Good morning. Let me start by describing how we think about CapEx in general. We prioritize all of our capital based on what is most critical to maintaining our operations and, of course, what's critical to maintaining the safety of all of o
componenttext: Thanks, Carl. Good morning. Let me start by describing how we think about CapEx in general. We prioritize all of our capital based on what is most critical to maintaining our operations and, of course, what's critical to maintaining the safety of all of our employees. That we certainly will not compromise. What we have looked at I scapital that we feel we can defer with limited risk to operational continuity. It may incur slightly higher cost in terms of operating over a short term, but we believe that the cash conservation is valuable. In terms of K3, our thinking has been ancillary equipment. Any of those type cost, yes, we will consider, but we are being very cognizant that we want to maintain the critical path of the K3 project. So on that basis, we're taking out cost we believe we can defer, but making sure we're not compromising the integrity of our business.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Adam Samuelson from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Adam Samuelson from Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a couple of questions on phosphate, if you don't mind. Maybe first, in the quarter, and you alluded to in the third quarter as well, your rock cost have been higher. Maybe a little bit more clarity about the drivers there. Second, you deferred or yo
componenttext: Maybe a couple of questions on phosphate, if you don't mind. Maybe first, in the quarter, and you alluded to in the third quarter as well, your rock cost have been higher. Maybe a little bit more clarity about the drivers there. Second, you deferred or you canceled the second ammonia barge related to the CF ammonia contract for next year. Can you talk about what volume capability that gives you under the terms of that agreement? If you can still take the full volumes or if not if there's any penalties associated with that? And then finally, on phosphate, just wanted to get your thoughts on India for the second half and confidence on Davenport.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Adam. Let me just put this some order here. And let me take them one at a time, and I'll probably hand the India second quarter over to Rick and Mike. But let me talk on rock cost. Clearly, on the long term, we've been able to manage our roc
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Adam. Let me just put this some order here. And let me take them one at a time, and I'll probably hand the India second quarter over to Rick and Mike. But let me talk on rock cost. Clearly, on the long term, we've been able to manage our rock costs extremely well in our Phosphate business. What's happening today is we've run into some what I would call short-term geology changes that have meant that the great or the amount of 4 that will be able to pull per tonne of mining is decreased at our Four Corners mine as 1 portion of the mine. We're talking about a decade-long reserves, and sometimes all those are variable. Sometimes we hit areas where the rock qualities much higher than we expect and other times we have rock quality that's maybe lower than what we expect. We do expect them to be transitory and in the long term, we hold it with our expectations of superior rock cost. In terms of the ammonia barge, we -- yes, we certainly can move volumes with the 1 ammonia barge. We have a little less buffer, I guess, would be the way I would put it. And maybe 5 or 6 years from now when we have to have some statue statutory shutdowns of those barges for repairs, there may be short periods of time where we have to come up with different plans. But overall, we believe we've managed the risk very well while still conserving as much cash as we can. Now in terms of the India second half, I'm just going to hand the straight over to Mike and let him talk about that.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good morning, Adam. Why don't I give you some numbers, and Rick, you can provide some color commentary here. Yes. In general, the outlook in India remains very positive. As you know, the monsoon is delivering above average rainfall. Retail prices or
componenttext: Okay. Good morning, Adam. Why don't I give you some numbers, and Rick, you can provide some color commentary here. Yes. In general, the outlook in India remains very positive. As you know, the monsoon is delivering above average rainfall. Retail prices or DAPR are up about 15%. The rupee has been very stable compared to other currencies and finally, imported margins, given all those parameters, are profitable. So all the stars and moons are lined up to make important economics work. We're projecting about 5.6 million tons of imports this calendar year in India. First half of the year, they imported 1.8. That would leave about 3.8 million tonnes second half of the year that we think they need to import into the country. And so that's a big number. It's 500,000 tonnes more than what they did last year, which was a very good second half for them. And on the comments here, we mentioned the bunching of demand in the second half of the year. I guess, when you put the 3.8 million  tons that India has to import alongside the 2.9 million tonnes we think Brazil needs to import plus the prospects were good North American season, we do believe that there will be some pretty strong seasonal posts on shipments second half of the year.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: A question on capital allocation. You talked about being in position to buy assets at the bottom of the cycle. I know you've been looking at phosphate assets in Brazil. I guess the question would be with the upcoming more the investment, what would you be looking to expand your phosphate production capability, the acquisition, particularly given where your own shares are trading, which would seem to be at a lower multiple of replacement cost than an acquisition might be?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Don. Between Rich and I, we'll answer that question. Let me start by saying we're -- we fundamentally believe that some of the best opportunities come at the low part of the cycle, so we'll continue to look at those opportunities. However
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Don. Between Rich and I, we'll answer that question. Let me start by saying we're -- we fundamentally believe that some of the best opportunities come at the low part of the cycle, so we'll continue to look at those opportunities. However, we'll always continue to be prudent of how we manage our balance sheet and our investment grade balance sheet in particular. We always look for opportunities that have long term  shareholders value. And I think we've said it before, each time we look at those, we measure thus against the value of buying back our own shares and how that looks for the long term. So we'll always take into account our normal capital allocation requirements and priorities and then balance the opportunity against that and the long-term opportunities gives us. Rich, do you want to add some color there?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Joc, and Don, the only thing that I would say is if you go back and take a look at the history of Mosaic and really, even the formation of Mosaic, there are periods of time when there are very strategic assets that do become available for sa
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Joc, and Don, the only thing that I would say is if you go back and take a look at the history of Mosaic and really, even the formation of Mosaic, there are periods of time when there are very strategic assets that do become available for sale and compelling opportunities do our rise. And so that has been our history in a number of acquisitions, likely to continue to be our history as we move forward. But I think as Jack noted, anything that we do has got to have a very high strategic fit and it goes through a very high bar in terms of investment analysis. And so certainly, one of the things that we would look at is the opportunity cost of not repurchasing our own shares.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess the last thing to leave this with us fundamentally, we believe there's room for consolidation in both the phosphates and the potash industry. We believe that there could be some real value added by that consolidation, so we're certainly not ag
componenttext: And I guess the last thing to leave this with us fundamentally, we believe there's room for consolidation in both the phosphates and the potash industry. We believe that there could be some real value added by that consolidation, so we're certainly not against consolidation and we think there could be some value added.

componenttext: I think in your quarter, your adjusted corporate gross margin was about negative $34 million. Why was that? And that's much larger than what you had in the first quarter why is your tax rate that going at 10%? And why in the future is there no more Canadian resource tax guidance?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I got it, Jeff. There's -- I mean, the elimination of profit in inventory in the corporate segment that really relates to the buildup of inventory in Brazil in anticipation of a large season coming up there. And then with respect to the Canad
componenttext: Yes, I think I got it, Jeff. There's -- I mean, the elimination of profit in inventory in the corporate segment that really relates to the buildup of inventory in Brazil in anticipation of a large season coming up there. And then with respect to the Canadian resource taxes, the increase this quarter was generally related to a catch-up accrual of about $10 million. And also, you have to take into account where the production is occurring and what the profitability is on a mine-by-mine basis. So with the shutdown of and less production there, more production coming out of Esterhazy and in particular leads to a slightly higher Canadian resource taxes this quarter, which I would expect to fall back to what I'll call more normal levels in the Q3 and Q4. And just as a reminder, this year or year-to-date, Canadian resource taxes are just slightly more than, I'll say, $50 million compared to last year where they were about $130 million to $140 million.

componenttext: I think it's probably best to straight to Mike and Rick to talk about how we're looking at this next quarter.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Mike, I think, I Mike covered it in his prepared comments talking about bunching of demand. And as we look at what we face so far for margins, we've seen impact from a strong U.S. dollar, deferred buying and effectively some increased pipeline invent
componenttext: Yes. Mike, I think, I Mike covered it in his prepared comments talking about bunching of demand. And as we look at what we face so far for margins, we've seen impact from a strong U.S. dollar, deferred buying and effectively some increased pipeline inventories that our customers hands. Those have cleaned themselves out, so we expect good North American and South American demand. A good indicator of South American demand is the fact that our distribution business took $300 million in prepayments from customers for all fertilizer products, which means that farmers there, it underpins the 32 million-tonne overall demand forecast that we've talked about for Brazil. So as we go through the quarter and through the third quarter and into the fourth quarter, we see margins improving as we've -- as demand starts to bunch up in all of those markets, India, Brazil, Argentina and North America.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, do you have any?
componenttext: Mike, do you have any?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the only thing I would add is I think it may get interesting from the middle of September to the middle of November as far as the seasonal bunching. And I think we're beginning to see evidence of a price uplift from demand finally coming to the ma
componenttext: I guess the only thing I would add is I think it may get interesting from the middle of September to the middle of November as far as the seasonal bunching. And I think we're beginning to see evidence of a price uplift from demand finally coming to the market. Barge prices have increased, CNF price in Brazil has moved up here recently, and we know that raw material prices for sulphur in the third quarter have come down $5, ammonia prices at 2 70 for August and I don't see much were threatened in terms of any uptick in those and potentially more downside as well. So put that altogether and, as we said, we're not wildly bullish, but we think that the combination of all of that is going to improve margins as we head into late third quarter and into the first part of fourth quarter.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me just sort of pull that together really quickly. Basically, what we're seeing is an increase in demands. We see a volume increase, which should lead to better cost in general because of the better usage or assets. And then in terms of margins, we
componenttext: So let me just sort of pull that together really quickly. Basically, what we're seeing is an increase in demands. We see a volume increase, which should lead to better cost in general because of the better usage or assets. And then in terms of margins, we're probably minor ability to improve from sulfur and ammonia perspective. So we see the cost being g fairly flat to down because of a higher operating rate. And then in terms of going forward into 2017, again, we see this market as fairly well-balanced, so we think '17 should be a fairly good year for our Phosphate business.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just very quickly, just the most produces that have reported as well as some of your international peers have increased North American potash fairly significantly during the first half of the year. And it also look like you just tweaked your regional
componenttext: And just very quickly, just the most produces that have reported as well as some of your international peers have increased North American potash fairly significantly during the first half of the year. And it also look like you just tweaked your regional guidance demand a bit. So can you just comment on what you believe inventory levels are relative to the beginning of the second quarter? And then how you expect this to flow into December and eventually the fall? Just any change there? And then also whether or not you're seeing an increase in consignment tonnes.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'm going to hand that back to Rick and Mike again to talk about our inventories and regional inventories.
componenttext: Okay. I'm going to hand that back to Rick and Mike again to talk about our inventories and regional inventories.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll start with just saying what our sales team has come back and reported is that after a very good spring where buyers bought their last tonne of both potash and phosphate, inventories -- pipeline inventories in the hands of retailers and distribut
componenttext: Yes. I'll start with just saying what our sales team has come back and reported is that after a very good spring where buyers bought their last tonne of both potash and phosphate, inventories -- pipeline inventories in the hands of retailers and distributors in North America have been run down and they are their lower levels than they were last year. We see continued movement in kind of a summer filled program happening right now, and prices -- uptake of those have been good in both P&K. And for ourselves, we have agreements with customers where we separate shipment from invoicing our FPV program. And frankly, we're seeing people step in and buy product that's in inventory right now as well as buy products that's coming to them. So frankly, we see very good solid position. Mike?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of numbers, the North American potash market has been a pretty stable market for a long term despite all the price and concerns about cutbacks and application rates. In 2015 calendar year, we think shipments were about 8.9 million tonnes, and we
componenttext: In terms of numbers, the North American potash market has been a pretty stable market for a long term despite all the price and concerns about cutbacks and application rates. In 2015 calendar year, we think shipments were about 8.9 million tonnes, and we think this year hinch up a little bit to 9 million tonnes and then drop off to -- back to about 8.9 million tonnes. But I think the important point there is when you look at the imports, imports surge to, by our account, about 1.4 million metric tonnes in calendar 2015. Those have come down. We think 2016 will end the year with a million tonnes and probably another reduction in 2017, largely because of the big price discount in North America that's just not as attractive to move tonnes into North America now. And there are better options with decent demand prospects in other parts of the world.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sandy Klugman from Vertical Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sandy Klugman from Vertical Research.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You highlighted the strength of the Brazilian agricultural industry. I was hoping you could comment on the credit environment and what type of access the capital Brazilian growers currently have for fertilizer purchases?
componenttext: You highlighted the strength of the Brazilian agricultural industry. I was hoping you could comment on the credit environment and what type of access the capital Brazilian growers currently have for fertilizer purchases?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start by saying we are seeing a great deal of improvement in terms of access to capital. I'm going to hand that to Rick to talk a little more in detail about it. But in general, we're seeing, as you've heard already, we're seeing a really good star
componenttext: Let me start by saying we are seeing a great deal of improvement in terms of access to capital. I'm going to hand that to Rick to talk a little more in detail about it. But in general, we're seeing, as you've heard already, we're seeing a really good start to the second half of the year in Brazil, including record prepay, and that record prepay is a good indication of credit availability. Rick, do you want to just give a little more color there?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that what we're seeing -- I don't think -- I know that what we're seeing there is at times when the green market has been where it's at and the currency is being frankly, where it's at today, those Brazilian farmers had stepped in because of
componenttext: Yes. I think that what we're seeing -- I don't think -- I know that what we're seeing there is at times when the green market has been where it's at and the currency is being frankly, where it's at today, those Brazilian farmers had stepped in because of the cost of crop nutrients compared to the price of grain is probably at its best level than it's been in the last 12 years. And so we're seeing farmers step up. Credit availability is, in a marketplace like Brazil that's still developing, is always going to be an issue, but we don't see any concentration to what we're selling there from permanent credibility standpoint.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add. Regardless of the conditions, they're getting the job done. First half shipments of all fertilizer products in Brazil were at a record level 13.1 -- 13.2 million metric tonnes are the largest amount of fertilizer that's ever been shipped in
componenttext: I'll just add. Regardless of the conditions, they're getting the job done. First half shipments of all fertilizer products in Brazil were at a record level 13.1 -- 13.2 million metric tonnes are the largest amount of fertilizer that's ever been shipped in the first half of the year. So that said, despite the political chaos, exchange rate concerns, credit concerns, they're getting fertilizer to the farm.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Oxgaard from Bernstein.

componenttext: A question on the cash generation. You were -- your earnings is almost nothing, yet you degenerated as much cash as you did last year in this quarter. Can you give a comment on that?

componenttext: Yes, we can comment on that for sure. I'll hand it to Rich to really give that detail. But I think the biggest piece of that is what you've just mentioned. I think some number of $360 million worth of prepay into Brazil is a heck of a lot of cash coming in and really makes a big difference to how we're setting up for the second half of the year. Rich, do you want to go through the full details of that?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's prepay, which is the large percentage of it, Jonas. And then it is a favorable working capital adjustments during the quarter. But you're right, it led to a very strong cash flow of nearly $600 million.
componenttext: Yes, it's prepay, which is the large percentage of it, Jonas. And then it is a favorable working capital adjustments during the quarter. But you're right, it led to a very strong cash flow of nearly $600 million.

componenttext: And I don't want to miss taking credit for some of the cost that we've actually reduced and some of the expenditures we haven't made, which again, has conserved cash through this period.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of P.J. Juvekar from Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of P.J. Juvekar from Citigroup.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quickly, I have a question on potash. And you're expecting potash [indiscernible] into the 4% next year, driven by inventory builds. And my question is really on China, but can that inventory situation or de-stocking continue next year? I look at Chinese
componenttext: Quickly, I have a question on potash. And you're expecting potash [indiscernible] into the 4% next year, driven by inventory builds. And my question is really on China, but can that inventory situation or de-stocking continue next year? I look at Chinese potash inventories and they're down from the peak. They're still quite high at 2 million tonnes. And then Changi Salt Lake is also adding over 0.5 million tonnes capacity in '16 and '17. So when you look at that, why do you think Chinese potash import will continue to grow?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. PJ, I'm going to handle a lot of this over to Mike Rahm, who does a heck of a lot of work on the world FND for potash, obviously. But we do see a rundown of Chinese inventory over this year. We continue to see more product go to the actual ground, w
componenttext: Okay. PJ, I'm going to handle a lot of this over to Mike Rahm, who does a heck of a lot of work on the world FND for potash, obviously. But we do see a rundown of Chinese inventory over this year. We continue to see more product go to the actual ground, which is what gets shipped is one thing. What actually gets used to produce crops is really what matters in the long term. So we do see China's need for potash fertilizer in particular continuing to grow, and they will have to supply that in the years to come as they have in the years to pass. But with that, I'm going to hand it to Mike to talk about the details of the FND.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. PJ, yes, China, as you know, is a bit complicated country. And frankly, I think, there's something going on there in terms of potash consumption. I think all the numbers would suggest that maybe potash consumption is a little bit better than anyone
componenttext: Okay. PJ, yes, China, as you know, is a bit complicated country. And frankly, I think, there's something going on there in terms of potash consumption. I think all the numbers would suggest that maybe potash consumption is a little bit better than anyone is giving China credit for. Just to review some of the numbers, China are importer of record 9.4 million tonnes last year. We think they produced about 6.6 million tonnes and shipments probably in that 16 million tonnes range, so there's a little bit of an inventory build last year. We think that's getting pulled down. Our shipment number this year is 12.9 million tonnes. With think that will increase to 13.9 million tonnes next year. So imports, we think imports this year probably will be in that 8 million tonnes range, so down from last year and it probably stays in that range for 2017. The other factor, you mentioned Shanghai Salt Lake. Our team in Beijing believes that production has dropped this year, probably closer to 6 million to -- 6.2 million tonnes. So while there's some additional capacity coming on, I think there's been some adjustment in terms of domestic production in response to the current price environment as well. But I think the bottom line is, yes, we don't have a record shipment number factored in for China next year, and we think imports are going to be relatively stable at about 8 million tonnes.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just talk a little bit about part inventories, which I think you mentioned the 2 million tonnes. I believe our last number was about 1.8 million tonnes. But Rick, remember, 1 million of that is in bonded warehouses, which will now get turned in
componenttext: And let me just talk a little bit about part inventories, which I think you mentioned the 2 million tonnes. I believe our last number was about 1.8 million tonnes. But Rick, remember, 1 million of that is in bonded warehouses, which will now get turned in sales fairly quickly. So the actual port inventory of nonbonded warehouses isn't as high as all that. The other thing you have to consider in China is upcountry inventory, which I think can play a big, big role in this. And what we're hearing from both our own distribution team and from is, is that this country inventory is certainly being depleted now. So thanks, PJ.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Jackson from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Jackson from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: When would you make a decision whether call in say will be ramp back up for '17? What would be the factors around it? It seems like considering some of the different things going on industry, the rope and go proving run, the legacy ramp, your demand preda
componenttext: When would you make a decision whether call in say will be ramp back up for '17? What would be the factors around it? It seems like considering some of the different things going on industry, the rope and go proving run, the legacy ramp, your demand predation, you may not need to call in tonnes for some time? And the second question, why would you be -- you did not lower your dividend like what one of your partners did last week. You're running maybe around 200% payout ratio right now. What would have to happen for you to revise your dividend?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay., Joe, thank you for this question. First, I mean, Colonsay's decision is clearly how do we meet our customer needs while optimizing our overall, cost and cash output. So we'll make -- we'll have to make another decision on Colonsay towards the end o
componenttext: Okay., Joe, thank you for this question. First, I mean, Colonsay's decision is clearly how do we meet our customer needs while optimizing our overall, cost and cash output. So we'll make -- we'll have to make another decision on Colonsay towards the end of the year. Our expectation at this stage is we will bring it up in January as per what we've previously announced. But I mean, really, the deciding factor there will be how much we think we'll need for our spring season and how well positioned we are at the end of the year for that spring season. But at this stage, we are expecting we will bring up Colonsay in January. In terms of the dividend, look, at this point, we don't plan to cut our dividend as you've said. We see the fundamentals improving in the second half of the year, which mitigates the need for a dividend cut. Now if the markets don't improve or if they deteriorate, we may have to revisit the affordability of our dividend. However, just let me point out in the first half of the year, we generated sufficient cash to cover all of our commitments, including capital and our dividend. So our $1 billion of cash is still intact and our $2.5 billion liquidity buffer is still intact. So we don't see an impending need to review our dividend at this stage. We leave that open, but we may in the future. And Rich, do you just want to add anything to that?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say, Joel, that obviously, it's something that we closely monitor and we'll continue to closely monitor in the future. Jack noted, we have a conservative liquidity buffer of $2.5 billion. Interestingly enough, we've never really dipped into t
componenttext: Yes. I would say, Joel, that obviously, it's something that we closely monitor and we'll continue to closely monitor in the future. Jack noted, we have a conservative liquidity buffer of $2.5 billion. Interestingly enough, we've never really dipped into the liquidity buffer in our history, and we've got over $1 billion of cash on the balance sheet. And at the same time, we are reducing our cash spend, so we're lowering our capital people, we're reducing our SG&A. We're maximizing working capital as much as we possibly can. And so this is something that we'll continue to review, obviously, with the mindset the maintaining a solid investment grade credit rating going forward.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Wong from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Wong from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you remind us on some of your CapEx requirements? How much is left for Esterhazy case 3? And what's the timing and CapEx phosphate mine development? I'll mine development in awhile. And just on your targeting leverage ratios and what that level curr
componenttext: Could you remind us on some of your CapEx requirements? How much is left for Esterhazy case 3? And what's the timing and CapEx phosphate mine development? I'll mine development in awhile. And just on your targeting leverage ratios and what that level currently is?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So first of all, CapEx. We are in the process today of looking at all of the opportunities and possibilities around a new phosphate mine. I think our latest says that we will need to have that in place by I think the 2023-type time frame. So certain
componenttext: Okay. So first of all, CapEx. We are in the process today of looking at all of the opportunities and possibilities around a new phosphate mine. I think our latest says that we will need to have that in place by I think the 2023-type time frame. So certainly, we're in the planning phase now. I'm trying to go back to our past Investor Day where I believe we said the cost of that would be circa $600 million now that we've spent -- we're expanding south pasture mine rather than building a brand new own mine. In terms of the capital requirements left for K3, we are largely finished the shafts sinking on K3. Our incremental costs going forward, not including what the save in taxes because of the write-downs of capital, would be in the range of $600 million. And those are for mine development infrastructure and conveyor ways between K3, K1 and K2.  In terms of our leverage targets, I'm going to hand that straight over to Rich to get the details.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Andrew, our leverage targets, as stated, are roughly between 1.5 and 2x, but keep in mind that, that is kind of a through cycle target. So at any given point, you're going to have a spot leverage ratio that may be higher or lower than that. And so we
componenttext: Yes. Andrew, our leverage targets, as stated, are roughly between 1.5 and 2x, but keep in mind that, that is kind of a through cycle target. So at any given point, you're going to have a spot leverage ratio that may be higher or lower than that. And so we look at it on a true cycle basis. Right now, we are slightly higher than the upper end of that range. But when you take a look at it as a rating agency would look at it over a, call it, a 3- to 5-year period for time, we're comfortable with where we're at right now. And, obviously, we're at the bottom end of the cycle.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Gulley of CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Gulley of CLSA.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following on the K3 comments. Does the goal of cutting CapEx influence how you're thinking about that transition or managing it? Are you looking to speed it up or slow it down? Or is that still open there? And then the second question, do you anticip
componenttext: Just following on the K3 comments. Does the goal of cutting CapEx influence how you're thinking about that transition or managing it? Are you looking to speed it up or slow it down? Or is that still open there? And then the second question, do you anticipate spending more on the Brazil distribution build-out in near term? Just wonder if you can give us an update there and let us the where there is still seeking to expand.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Mark, thank you. So first of all, let's talk about K3 and then move on to Brazil. What we've said today is we will continue on the critical path of K3 piece. So the big thing right now is finishing the shaft sinking build the loading pockets, build
componenttext: Okay. Mark, thank you. So first of all, let's talk about K3 and then move on to Brazil. What we've said today is we will continue on the critical path of K3 piece. So the big thing right now is finishing the shaft sinking build the loading pockets, build the infrastructure so that we can start mining the e K3. How fast we ramp that up greatly depends on market conditions and what the needs are for product at that stage. So that, I think, is going to come in a couple of years when we really need to what's going on there. But in general, I would say if times are tougher, it would push you more towards moving from K1 and K2 to K3 earlier to reduce the brine inflow cost. But I think that decisions is aways out. In terms of Brazil distribution, we believe our footprint right now is pretty strong in Brazil. We like where we stand. Over the longer term, we can see ourselves expanding into the Northwest into areas of and towards the northern region, towards Amazonia. But in the near term, the only expansion plans that we will consider is if we need to expand our port capacity at ParanaguÃ¡, which we may feel we need for good logistics.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Edlain Rodriguez from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Edlain Rodriguez from UBS.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one quick question. I mean, before, you've talked about the potential for potash prices to move higher in the near term. So like how does the softness in crop prices play or in? Farmers will tends to either to pay up or not, especially in the U.S.?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Edwin. Let me start by just highlighting that certainly lower crop prices does impact, at least the psychology of fertilizer. Having said that, fertilizers very affordable to the farmer right now. Our fertilizer-to-crop price ratio is pro
componenttext: Well, thank you, Edwin. Let me start by just highlighting that certainly lower crop prices does impact, at least the psychology of fertilizer. Having said that, fertilizers very affordable to the farmer right now. Our fertilizer-to-crop price ratio is probably as good as it's been in a long long time. But recognize that the impact, the soft crops prices are driven by higher risk. And those higher yields means higher fertilizer removed from the soil and so that in itself tends to drive higher demand. The other thing I want to highlight on that is we talk about soft crop prices, we normally are talking about corn. If corn acres goes down in the U.S., for instance, they will probably be replaced by soybean acres. And so likely for us, there won't be that big an impact. And also remember, only 30% of fertilizers are used on the corn, wheat, bean complex. The rest is crops like sugar, coffee, which are doing very well. So with that, Mike, did you want to add anything to that?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's a good question and certainly a concern that we have an monitor. I think one of the things, yes, we had a very good run in prices in June, and our intelligence tells us that farmers sold pretty heavily into that as well as probably for
componenttext: Yes. I think that's a good question and certainly a concern that we have an monitor. I think one of the things, yes, we had a very good run in prices in June, and our intelligence tells us that farmers sold pretty heavily into that as well as probably forward price some of their 2016 crop. So I don't think you want us to focus too much on current spot prices. Clearly, there's a big crop that's coming in shortly and that's impacting prices now. But there's still a fair amount of uncertainty about what happens in the southern hemisphere, particularly with the expectation of the La NiÃ±a event and the negative consequence that typically has for the Southern Hemisphere harvest. So if you look at the 2017 new crop prices, they're still at levels that are that we think underpin the decent demand. And as Joc said, we're very much corn, soybean, wheat focused. And the 30% number Joc referred to is a 30% of the potash worldwide is applied to those 3 crops. The phosphates is about 40%. So the fact that you're seeing dramatic increase in sugar prices, cotton prices, coffee prices, fruits and vegetables, those are the ones that are going to I think provide a very good demand base.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vincent. I'm going to hand all of this over to Rick, but let me start by saying we expect to see you expect the growth of agricultural output, and as such, the use of fertilizers to grow at about a 5% per year in Brazil over the next number of
componenttext: Thank you, Vincent. I'm going to hand all of this over to Rick, but let me start by saying we expect to see you expect the growth of agricultural output, and as such, the use of fertilizers to grow at about a 5% per year in Brazil over the next number of years so we expect that to continue. And in terms of the softness and the underlying prices, most of the projections show a continued weak real or even a weakening real, which all bodes very well for the economics of farming in Brazil. So we expect '17 to be another good year. I don't have the exact numbers, mike can give you those. But in terms of ongoing growth, we expect 5% a year for the next number of years. Mike, do you want to give the specifics there?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Vincent, yes, we see the demand continuing to grow in Brazil. We're projecting potash shipments about 9.1 million tonnes this year, increasing to 9.4 million tonnes next year. And of that, imports going from 8.5 million this year to 9 million  tonnes
componenttext: Yes. Vincent, yes, we see the demand continuing to grow in Brazil. We're projecting potash shipments about 9.1 million tonnes this year, increasing to 9.4 million tonnes next year. And of that, imports going from 8.5 million this year to 9 million  tonnes next year. So very good demand prospects there. We see the real probably remain fairly stable, and yet the local currency prices of the key crops in Brazil remaining attractive and causing more acreage antiques and input usage. In the case of phosphates in terms of input demand, we think imports of that map, PSN PSP will go from about 5.2 million tonnes this year to 5.6 million  tonnes next year. And so yes, there's nothing at this point that we see that sort of derails the growth trajectory that we're seeing in Brazil. I don't know, Rick, do you have any comments?

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd go back something that Joc mentioned and it's really around farmer economics. At today's grain prices despite softening the currency where it is, returns for this crop that will be planted and harvested and planted this fall and harvest
componenttext: The only thing I'd go back something that Joc mentioned and it's really around farmer economics. At today's grain prices despite softening the currency where it is, returns for this crop that will be planted and harvested and planted this fall and harvested in January, February are very, very good. And the prospects for the '17, '18 crop are just the same. So that really underpins demand. Farmers needing the product to get the yields that they need plus having good solid economics.

On the same note, if you talk about bunching of demand into 2H 2016, why is your phosphate price or DAP price range at the top of its range flat with current pricing? componenttext: Thank you, Jonas. So we'll hit these one at a time. First of all, Brazil, I think we're seeing some potash improvements in terms of near-term pricing in Brazil. There's been some $10, $20 up in the last couple of weeks, and we expect that to continue as we get closer to the remaining planting season. I'll let work and Mike just talk about that quickly. And the next question is why is pricing flat despite the bunching? I mean, we would go for an improvement in both margin and pricing in the second half, but we need to see the demand first and then the price will follow.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Jonas, we said there's some bunching in the second half. We think that the impact on price probably doesn't show up in spades until probably the maybe second half of September. I talked about things probably getting interesting from the second half of September through the second half of -- through the first half of November, and that's when peak demand is going to be hitting in terms of shipments into the big market, so whether it's India, Brazil, North America. And so I think that's reflected in our third quarter price projections.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to conclude our call, I just want to reinforce our key points. The business environments remains tough, but we see signs of stability and improvement. We expect strong global demand and modest improving prices in the second half of the year. In Mosaic,
componenttext:
So to conclude our call, I just want to reinforce our key points. The business environments remains tough, but we see signs of stability and improvement. We expect strong global demand and modest improving prices in the second half of the year. In Mosaic, we're taking the necessary actions to withstand the current environment and thrive the markets to improve. We're conserving cash by cutting our costs and our capital spending. We are continually looking for opportunities to create shareholder value now and into the years ahead. 
So thank you very much for joining us. Have a great day.

headline: The Mosaic Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
